channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Saudi Forces Agree to Halt in Yemen War
item.description: A Saudi-led military coalition announced on Saturday that a five-day humanitarian cease-fire would take effect in Yemen starting Sunday evening at the request of Yemen’s exiled president.
item.dc:creator: SHUAIB ALMOSAWA and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Israel Is Steadfast in Criticism of Nuclear Deal
item.description: An Israeli official said his government would continue to call on Congress to reject the Iran nuclear accord and could not be pressured to stop voicing its objections.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Turkey, Anticipating Attack, Strikes 3 ISIS Targets in Syria With Jets
item.description: The strikes came a day after Turkey’s first reported direct combat with the Islamic State, and its granting of permission to American warplanes to conduct strikes from two of its air bases.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: A protester in Istanbul on Friday took aim at a police vehicle at a demonstration against an operation attacking Kurdish militants.

item.title: Times Article on Rome’s Decay Draws a Surge of New Scrutiny
item.description: A New York Times article on Romans’ complaints about the decline of the quality of life in their city lit up Italian news media and social networks.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rickshaws carrying tourists on the road leading to the Colosseum last week. The mayor of Rome, Ignazio Marino, closed the road to local traffic as soon as he took office, with the idea of creating a pedestrian way.

item.title: Seeking Sanctuary, More Migrants Confront Land Route’s Perils
item.description: As refugees continue to flow from the Middle East, Africa and Afghanistan, an increasingly popular path to Western Europe proves rigorous and risky.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Afghan read the Quran as he waited with a group of migrants near the border.

item.title: Opinion: Greece, the Sacrificial Lamb
item.description: The conditions imposed on the country make it a kind of debtors’ prison.
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH E. STIGLITZ
item.media:description: The frayed flag over Athens last week.

item.title: Obama Administration Targets Trade in African Elephant Ivory
item.description: Adding to existing federal laws, the rule changes announced on Saturday would amount to a near total ban on the commercial trade of African elephant ivory in the United States.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and JADA F. SMITH

item.title: Tunisia Passes Antiterror Law After 2 Deadly Attacks
item.description: Tunisia’s Parliament voted overwhelmingly late Friday to pass an antiterrorism law after a pair of devastating attacks against tourists, but critics fear that the new legislation may endanger the country’s hard-won freedoms.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Tunisian lawmakers on Friday debated the law, which had languished in Parliament for years.

item.title: A Terrorism Case in Britain Ends in Acquittal, but No One Can Say Why
item.description: A group of journalists are among the very few people who know why a student was finally acquitted of terrorism charges. Problem is, they cannot report what they know.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: News Analysis: Spy’s Release Is Unlikely to Assuage Israel on Iran Nuclear Deal
item.description: Attempts in Washington to highlight the likely parole of an Israeli spy in hopes of quieting a campaign against the Iran deal could provoke a backlash, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: The federal prison in Butner, N.C., where the Israeli spy Jonathan J. Pollard is being held. He is likely to receive parole in November, having served the required 30 years of a life sentence.

item.title: For Ransom, Bitcoin Replaces the Bag of Bills
item.description: These days, there’s a new preferred method for hostage takers: the virtual currency Bitcoin.
item.dc:creator: NATHANIEL POPPER
item.media:description: A Bitcoin conference and trade show in New York last year. The currency was unveiled by an anonymous creator in 2009.

item.title: Obama in Kenya: An Upbeat Tone, but Notes of Discord, Too
item.description: Declaring that “Africa is on the move,” President Obama on Saturday lauded the economic development that has transformed parts of the continent.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and MARC SANTORA
item.media:description: President Obama spoke at the Global Entrepreneurship Summit meeting in Nairobi, Kenya, on Saturday.

item.title: Australia Arrests Nurse Who Says He Worked With ISIS Under Duress
item.description: Adam Brookman, who says he was wounded in an airstrike and then forced to work with ISIS, was arrested at the Sydney airport, the Australian police said.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Turkey Attacks Kurdish Militant Camps in Northern Iraq
item.description: The strikes, which followed Turkish attacks on Islamic State targets in Syria, effectively ended a two-year cease-fire between Turkey and the Kurdistan Workers’ Party.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: In Pakistan, Detainees Are Vanishing in Covert Jails
item.description: Dozens have died in military detention amid accounts of torture, starvation and extrajudicial execution from ex-captives, relatives and rights monitors.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: TAHA SIDDIQUI and DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: Pakistani police officers escorting the wife of a missing person at a demonstration protesting secret detentions in Islamabad, Pakistan, last year.

item.title: U.S. Fears Data Stolen by Chinese Hacker Could Identify Spies
item.description: The potential exposure of the American intelligence officers could prevent a large number of them from being posted abroad again.
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI and DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: World Briefing: Ukraine: U.S. Expands Aid to Train Regular Army Troops
item.description: The modest expansion of nonlethal military assistance will begin with training this fall for Ukrainian Army personnel in the western part of the country.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW SIDDONS

item.title: World Briefing: Chile: 7 in Pinochet’s Military Charged in Death of Protester
item.description: A judge charged them in the burning death of a 19-year-old American in 1986 during a protest against the dictatorship then in power.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Kerry Says Israel May Deepen Its Isolation by Opposing Iran Nuclear Accord
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry said the deal with Iran was in Israel’s interest, but several foreign policy experts said his remarks risked worsening relations between the countries.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry on Friday at the Council on Foreign Relations in New York to speak about the Iran accord.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Why Greece Should Leave the Eurozone
item.description: The country needs an orderly way to become competitive.
item.dc:creator: HANS-WERNER SINN
